awd_titl_txt: Improving Undergraduate Computer Science Education via Reading Group Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Digital technologies have spread to virtually every sector of the economy, increasing the demand for a workforce able to creatively apply their computational skills to diverse societal problems. Undergraduate research experiences encourage curiosity and creativity, but are difficult to scale due to inherent time constraints on faculty mentors. This project will study the benefits of exploratory reading groups as a scalable strategy for undergraduate computer science (CS) education and workforce development.  In exploratory reading groups, teams of students explore areas that interest them by selecting, reading, and discussing research papers.  Reading groups in other fields have been shown to foster supportive peer networks and intellectual curiosity, both of which are critical to student retention, especially for diverse student populations. It is anticipated that participating in exploratory reading groups will help CS students develop a big-picture view of how computer science is done, as well as provide peer support and promote their curiosity.  This project also seeks to contribute to computer-based approaches for forming student groups and to generate new knowledge about factors that influence group stability and effectiveness. This project has the potential to impact students' abilities to form and use groups as support networks in the future computing workplace. 

This project's long-term educational goal is to expand opportunities for curiosity-driven learning. It aims to adapt the traditional use of reading groups, typically focused on developing critical thinking skills, to the goal of fostering curiosity and creativity in computer science through exploration of topics of students' choosing. The project has four objectives: (1) Adapt the materials, structure, and supporting platforms used in non-computer science reading groups through a student-centered process, and evaluate their impact on educational outcomes through a two-year longitudinal study. (2) Study the use of everyday productivity tools as a generalizable means for: a) collecting student-generated content in face-to-face activities; b) enhancing papers with related courses and articles; and c) providing personalized recommendations. (3) Develop and evaluate heuristic algorithms for group formation that maximize participation, given student preferences. (4) Evaluate the collective knowledge system of the reading groups to understand capacity for participants to tap into their past reading group communities to find needed information. The validated processes, materials, and code for platforms and algorithms developed over the course of the project will be open sourced. A digital platform for educators will also be created, primarily for exploratory purposes. Instructions will be provided for educators to set up their own open-source platforms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the increasing role computation is playing in society, there is a growing need to educate a diverse workforce that can creatively apply computation to diverse societal problems. Yet most students don?t get exposed to the creative and motivating aspects of computing until much later in their junior and senior years, which is particularly concerning given the established importance of this type of exposure for the success of underrepresented students. Programs such as undergraduate research experiences (UREs) have helped with this, but are often only accessible to selective students due to their resource-intensive requirements.

This NSF-sponsored project from the Tech4Good Lab (tech4good.soe.ucsc.edu) developed exploratory reading groups to address this challenge. Exploratory Reading Groups provide an alternative to UREs, in which students can explore the creative aspects of computing as early as freshman year, in a low time-commitment manner, and in a relational small-group environment. Importantly, they are scalable due to their resource-light and student-driven design. Our SIGCSE publication describes the design principles underlying the program developed through a design-based research process, the diverse ways in which students gained value from exploration, the strong relational ties that developed, and the three clusters of participant motivations and experiences that emerged.

In the course of carrying out the project, we stumbled on an unexpected insight: not only were Exploratory Reading Groups effective as an alternative for UREs, they were also enhancing UREs themselves by establishing a pipeline into research labs. This led us to pivot our investigations to understanding faculty perspectives on UREs. Our ICER publication describes our synthesis of the barriers we identified around the theme of misalignments: misalignments between the educational system and the research system, misalignments between faculty and student goals, misalignments between student expectations and the realities of research, and the struggle to reach and maintain steady state when trying to overcome these misalignments.

Exploratory Reading Groups help address these misalignments. Since they are low time commitment and student-run, they circumvent barriers of limited time and meet student goals without imposing heavy barriers on faculty. As students explore research, interact with lab representatives, and receive encouragement from peers, they develop greater clarity in interests, realistic expectations, and motivation to apply. Our ASEE paper discusses how designing lightweight, scalable, and relational programs can help overcome system-level challenges in education and a submitted paper explores challenges of designing platforms that support individuals in forming small groups with others to learn in similar lightweight, scalable, and relational ways.

Beyond the intellectual contributions the project has made, the success of the program resulted in recognition from leadership on campus and institutionalization of the program as a 1-credit course, with campus backing to scale up the program to reach all students and to have every engineering faculty sponsor a reading group theme. Our IUSE Disruptor Blog article shares about this work with a broad audience, and resources and an in-progress platform for running Exploratory Reading Groups have been open-sourced and can be found at tech4good.soe.ucsc.edu/#/exploratory-reading-groups along with a detailed Playbook for Exploratory Reading Groups that steps readers through setting up Exploratory Reading Groups on their campus from the startup phase to a growth phase and to institutionalization. The program currently serves hundreds of students each year at UC Santa Cruz and continues to grow.
